intro: Milium alexeenkoi, commonly known as the Siberian millet, is a flowering plant native to the cold climates of Siberia and Central Asia. It belongs to the grass family, Poaceae, and is characterized by its small, delicate flowers that bloom in dense clusters. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 centimeters and has narrow, grass-like leaves. It is often found in rocky or sandy soils and is adapted to survive in harsh, arctic conditions. Due to its unique ecological role and ornamental value, it is sometimes cultivated in botanical gardens.
